stimulusHtml:
Nostri tamen, quod neque ordines servare neque firmiter insistere neque signa
 subsequi poterant atque alius alia ex navi quibuscumque signis occurrerat se
 adgregabat, magnopere perturbabantur; hostes vero, notis omnibus vadis, ubi ex
 litore aliquos singulares ex navi egredientes conspexerant, incitatis equis impeditos
5adoriebantur, plures paucos circumsistebant, alii ab latere aperto in universos tela
 coiciebant. Quod cum animadvertisset Caesar, scaphas longarum navium, item
 speculatoria navigia militibus compleri iussit, et quos laborantes conspexerat, his
 subsidia submittebat.

Bellum Gallicum 4. 26

Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question.

1. What are the case and use of alia (line 2) ?

2. In lines 3-6 (hostes . . . coiciebant), which three Latin words indicate that the enemies were fighting in their native land?

3. What are the case and number of tela (line 5) ?

4. In lines 3-6 (hostes . . . coiciebant), which two Latin words mean that the enemy attacked some of the Roman soldiers who were heavily weighed down?

5. Which Latin word in this passage is the subject of coiciebant (line 6) ?

6. In lines 6-8 (Quod . . . submittebat), which three Latin words can be translated as “the men whom he had seen having difficulty”?

7. In lines 6-8 (Quod . . . submittebat), (A) what are the two different kinds of ships in which Caesar sends reinforcements? (B) Give the Latin words for each.

8. In lines 6-8 (Quod . . . submittebat), what general feature of Caesar’s Commentarii is illustrated?

9. (A) Identify three pluperfect verbs in this passage and (B) translate them in context.
